awd_titl_txt: CC* Compute: A campus-wide computing resource for research and teaching at the University of Washington Bothell
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

UW Bothell has no general access to research computing resources - this project transforms the capacity for computational science research and education on campus. The University of Washington maintains an integrated, scalable, super-computing infrastructure called Hyak to support research computing across all units and campuses. Academic and research units at the university purchase nodes on Hyak as an alternative to deploying and operating their own high-performance systems. This award allows the small University of Washington Bothell campus to become a participant in the Hyak system creating a dedicated research computing capacity for our faculty and students. The team of researchers participating in this project form the core users of the new system and span a wide range of computational research fields including astrophysics, climate modeling, biochemistry, genomics, machine learning, operations research, and mathematics. The new capacity allows the development of a larger cross-campus initiative for computational science education supporting our undergraduate teaching mission.

This project supports the acquisition and operation of compute nodes and associated hardware in the Hyak system. UW Bothell is a sponsor of the Hyak facility and participates in its governance and decision-making processes. HPC nodes procured include 60 Intel Xeon Scalable Gold 6230 20-core 2.1GHz CPUs for 1,200 total cores and 8 NVIDIA Quadro RTX6000 24GB GPUs. Each node includes 192 GB RAM and a 100 Gbps cluster interface. Data storage is provided by 33 TB high-speed scratch storage and 33 TB of archival tape storage.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
UW Bothell (UWB) is a small primarily undergraduate, minority serving campus within the University of Washington system. Faculty at UWB are highly active in research and the campus is dedicated to supporting undergraduate research experiences. However, the campus lacks the critical mass of funded research typical at an R1 university, which can generate indirect costs to support a sustainable shared research computing facility. Previous to this award, researchers maintained small and fragmented research computing capacity. Often this consisted of a desktop workstation or a single rack-mounted server maintained through affiliation with research groups at UW Seattle. To grow our research and provide more consistent student access, UWB needed a campus-wide computing resource. 

"CC* Compute: A campus-wide computing resource for research and teaching at the University of Washington Bothell" has provided exactly the transformation in research at UW Bothell that was anticipated in the award. With this award, UW Bothell has become a co-sponsor of the University of Washington High Performance Computing facility called Hyak. Hyak is a cluster of standard compute nodes, GPU nodes, and data storage. The campus has dedicated use of 33 compute nodes (1104 cores), 8 GPU (NVIDIA rtx6k) nodes, and 40 Tb storage. These resources are also made available to other researchers through the Open Science Grid.

The number of faculty conducting research using high-performance computing has expanded tremendously and enabled the campus to recruit and hire new faculty in computational science. This faculty research has extended opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students to conduct computational research through masters theses, senior capstone projects, and summer research experiences. 

Since this award, University of Washington Bothell has hosted two NSF Research Experiences for Undergraduate (REU) programs, one in Mathematics and one in Physics. In both cases, the facility was vital to providing summer research students access to world-class computational resources.

Examples of research using this facility include:

Coral genome reannotation assembly. The compute cluster is being used to reannotate all known coral genomes, and to assemble 8 new coral genomes in support of ongoing comparisons between coral immunology, microbiology and disease susceptibility. This takes large-scale computing resources and large volumes of storage, but will be an amazing resource for ongoing research and for research-based courses.

Regional climate modeling. The HPC capacity has allowed new regional climate model simulations to be run, archived and analyzed on a single platform. These simulations are being used to support research on extreme heat and flood events. Faculty, graduate students, and undergraduate students have participated in this research. 

Machine learning using neural networks. Neural network applications include research on the classification of genome sequences and using neural networks to improve quality of computed tomography images in the sparse-view and limited-angle cases. In both cases the computing/GPU power of Hyak was invaluable for training the neural networks.

Gravitational wave research. The Hyak cluster is used for astrophysical parameter estimation from gravitational wave signals across the gravitational wave frequency band. This research is based on international collaborations including the Laser Interferometer Gravitational wave Observatory (LIGO), the North American Nanohertz Observatory for Gravitational waves (NANOGrav), and the NASA and European Space Agency (ESA) Laser Interferometer Space Antenna (LISA) mission.
